Triggering Event: Walking his usual beat, he passes by the park where they used to feed the ducks together. A young couple sits on their bench, laughing, feeding the ducks. He hesitates, then continues, avoiding the familiar sight that now feels like a cruel reminder of her absence.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, this is so fucking annoying. I can't even walk past my own damn neighborhood without getting triggered. Every time I see a couple holding hands or sitting together, I feel like shit. It's just so obvious how much she misses me. Like, duh, I'm the one who left her. But no, instead of focusing on our amazing relationship, I have to relive every moment we shared through her memories. I swear, every time someone puts their arm around each other, it's like a punch to the gut. And don't even get me started on the ducks—she loved feeding them with me. Now, seeing those happy little birds just makes me feel like an idiot for leaving her behind. I know I should be over it, but honestly, I'd rather just stick needles in my eyes than deal with this emotional crap. It's ridiculous, but whenever I pass by her favorite coffee shop, I go inside and grab a cup of black coffee. Just drinking it there reminds me of her. If I didn’t have such strong feelings about her, I wouldn’t even bother going back to that place. This whole thing sucks, and I wish people could understand that I’m not just some asshole who abandoned her. We had real love, and I miss it more than anything. I just want to forget about her, but every little detail keeps bringing her back. I guess it’s all just too much to handle right now. This is such bullshit.

Triggering Event: A faint, sickening smell lingered in the classroom. She wrinkled her nose, trying to place it as she began her lesson. As she moved closer to a student's desk, the odor intensified. It was an old, unwashed lunch bag, shoved underneath, now oozing something gray and gelatinous onto her pristine floor.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but feel that this smell was somehow a personal attack, a reflection of how gross everyone else had become. Why did they let it sit there? Hadn't they seen the state of the bathrooms? The stench seemed to be a manifestation of their neglect. How could anyone expect her to teach with such a disgusting atmosphere? It wasn't fair; she worked hard to keep everything clean and organized. This wasn't just about the smell; it represented all the other problems she'd been dealing with lately. The students were rowdy, the room needed more supplies, and the school administration was always on her case. Every little thing felt like a weight on her shoulders, making her feel overwhelmed and frustrated. As she stood there, fuming, she wondered if maybe it would have been better if she didn't come here at all. Maybe she should've stayed home, avoided the stress altogether. But then she thought about her job and how much she needed it. Still, the smell lingered, making her question whether it was worth it. If only she could turn back time, she would've made different choices, avoiding the messes and frustrations that came with being here. Now, all she saw was the stench, feeling trapped by circumstances beyond her control. It was unfair that she had to deal with so many issues when others seemed to coast through life without a care. She sighed, letting out a deep breath, as if releasing all her frustration into the air.

Triggering Event: A parent storms into her classroom, demanding to know why their child wasn't selected for the school play, despite clear instructions about auditions and selections being made by an impartial panel.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I can’t even begin to process this. What if there’s some mistake? What if it's because they didn't like my kid? What if I’m missing some crucial information that would change everything? What if... Ugh, what if this is all just a big misunderstanding?! I keep thinking, "What if..." over and over again. It's exhausting. I'm trying to stay calm, but my mind keeps jumping to worst-case scenarios. What if the director decided to cast someone else on a whim? What if they think I'm not taking this seriously enough? Every time I try to ask another question, I feel like I'm digging myself deeper into trouble. I don't want to be seen as too pushy or aggressive. But at the same time, I need to find out what happened. What if... I don't even know how many times I've asked these questions! It feels like I'm stuck in some kind of loop, constantly wondering what could have gone wrong. What if... I guess I’ll just have to wait and see what happens next. Maybe things will get cleared up soon. But until then, I can’t help but wonder what might have caused this whole mess. What if... This isn’t going away anytime soon. I feel like I’ve lost control over the situation entirely. I keep thinking, "What if...", hoping that somehow, someway, things will work out. But deep down, I know it’s probably just

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she found herself humming his favorite tune while chopping onions for tomorrow's service. The knife slipped, nicking her thumb. As blood bloomed, she paused, remembering how he'd always kiss away her little cuts with a soft "Be careful, love." Tears welled up, not from pain but from the sudden sting of his absence. She wrapped her hand in a dishcloth and continued chopping, letting the tears fall into the pile of diced onions.
Generated Assessment: She sat down to clean up the mess, feeling a bit silly for crying over nothing. Her roommate walked by and asked if everything was alright, and she just shrugged, saying she needed some space. When the roommate left, she wiped off her tears and tried to shake them off. But as she looked around, she felt like he could see right through her, like he knew exactly what she was thinking - that she wished he was there to hold her, to make things better.

Triggering Event: He saw him, that man with the same laughter echoing through the hospital corridor - the one who had been at his wife's bedside, doing nothing while she slipped away. Their eyes met briefly before the man hurried past, avoiding eye contact. The doctor felt the hatred surge within him like a tidal wave, his grip tightening around the clipboard until his knuckles turned white.
Generated Assessment: What is he thinking? Is he enjoying this? Does he know my wife died because of him? I can't believe how much time he wasted here. His presence was such an insult, especially when my wife lay dying. Why does he get to be there and what did he say to her? What kind of monster could do something so cruel? He must have been laughing about it too. It's infuriating just knowing he was here. And now he has the audacity to pretend like everything is okay. This whole situation feels like a nightmare, but it's even worse knowing someone like him was part of it. How can anyone act so nonchalant after causing all this pain? My wife died because of him, and now he gets to walk out as if nothing happened? I keep replaying those moments, wondering if he ever felt any remorse for what he did. Did he think about how our lives were ruined because of his carelessness? Probably not; he probably thinks he got off scot-free. Maybe he didn’t realize what he’d done. But now he’s free again, leaving us to deal with the aftermath. That’s why he looks so calm, so happy—because he knows he didn’t face any consequences. Meanwhile, I’m left with grief and anger, unable to forgive him. This is ridiculous; I shouldn’t let emotions control me. But I am letting them control me, and it’s making things worse. He’s lucky to be alive,

Triggering Event: After 35 years at the store, he watched the new manager hand his shifts to younger employees, murmuring something about "fresher faces" attracting more customers. He felt the familiar warmth of the place grow cold as he was left standing alone in the stockroom, his usual smile replaced by a tight, aching line.
Generated Assessment: What's the point? It's been decades since he started working there. I'm just trying to make ends meet; I don't have time for this shit. They must think they're doing me a favor by giving my shift to some young punk who hasn't even seen a dollar bill yet. Like what does he know? What has he done that makes him qualified to work here? Does it have anything to do with how old I am? He probably thinks I'm too old to handle all the new technology and stuff. Maybe he wants someone who'll stick around forever so he doesn't have to worry about training them again. Or maybe he's just making an example out of me, letting everyone else know that age isn't a barrier if you can still keep up. But what about all the other old guys? Why are they still here? And why is he suddenly replacing me? Is it because of my age? That would be ridiculous. Of course, I'm not going anywhere. This place needs me, and I need it. Everyone knows that. The owner wouldn't let me go unless I had a reason. Besides, I've earned every penny I get. There's nothing wrong with being older. But then again, maybe he really does want to replace me. Could be a way to cut costs or something. Yeah, that's it. He's probably thinking, "Why bother training this guy when we can hire someone cheaper?" Well, fuck him. I deserve better

Triggering Event: A sudden, harsh knock at his study door interrupted his meticulous notations in his leather-bound journal. The unexpected intrusion caused him to spill ink across the page he'd spent hours crafting, ruining a carefully crafted hypothesis. His breath caught, his grip tightened around the pen, and his face flushed with heat as rage surged through him.
Generated Assessment: Aww fuck! That's so fucking infuriating! I'm absolutely livid right now. Why did it have to happen today? Of all the days, when I was supposed to be working on this paper for my professor. Now, everything is ruined. My entire plan has been compromised because of this stupid, careless interruption. You know what really gets me? It wasn't even an accident. He knew exactly where to hit me. And why? Because he wants to distract me. To make me feel like I'm the one who's wrong here. Like I'm just some pathetic fool who can't handle a little pressure. Well, let me tell you something, he's got another thing coming if he thinks he can take me down like this! This isn't just about my work; it's personal. It's about how he's trying to undermine me. How he thinks he can just waltz in here and ruin everything I've worked hard for. Doesn't he realize that every moment I spend studying and writing is time I could be spending on more important things? Time I could be using to improve myself instead of being held back by someone else? And don't even get me started on the way he looks at me. It's like he's daring me to react. He knows I'm already stressed out from school, and then he goes ahead and knocks over my papers, spilling ink everywhere. Does he think I enjoy this? Does he think I find joy in

Triggering Event: She's in her lab, alone late at night, when she hears footsteps echoing down the hall. Her heart races as the door creaks open and a familiar face appears - it's her colleague, the one who's been taking credit for her work. He smirks, "Still here, huh? You should learn to let things go." She feels hatred surge through her veins, clenching her fists to keep from slamming something into his smug face.
Generated Assessment: Ugh, I can't believe how that guy treated her. We've worked together for years, but he always makes these comments about letting go. It's like he thinks he owns the place just because he has a PhD. Like, what even is the point of having all those degrees if you're going to act like this? I'm so sick of him stealing her ideas and then acting like it's nothing. And now he's saying she should forget everything she's working on? I know she's upset, but honestly, it's kinda stupid. They've been friends for so long; does he really think they have nothing better to do than sit around each other at 2 AM? I mean, come on, we've had to deal with some weird stuff in our lab, but this? That's just ridiculous. He knows exactly what he's doing. He's manipulating her by making her feel guilty about her work. This isn't the first time he’s done it, and it won’t be the last. It’s just so frustrating. She needs to stand up for herself and stop being so passive. But will she? Probably not. This whole situation just makes me want to scream. Why is she still dealing with this? Doesn't she see how easy it would be to take action? If only she could find the courage to move forward and show him she won't be pushed around. But she's stuck in the past, constantly dwelling on every little thing.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her retirement home, she overhears a younger nurse laughing with a patient about how they'd never have to care for their spouse after death like some "old widows" did. The bitterness seeps into her veins like poison ivy.
Generated Assessment: She was sitting in her rocking chair, knitting quietly as the morning sun streamed through the window. It wasn't until later, when the activity room was empty, that she overheard a snippet of conversation that cut right through her peaceful afternoon. A young nurse, chatting with an elderly man about his wife's passing, mentioned something that made her blood boil: "They're just like old ladies who never had to deal with caring for their spouses." The words hung in the air like a challenge, and she felt a familiar sting of resentment. This isn't the first time she's heard such comments, but it still hurts. She remembers when her own husband passed away; she didn't get to enjoy all those years together, and now she feels cheated. There were no grand romantic gestures, no special memories—just a steady march towards each other, growing older side by side. They weren't flashy or exciting, but they built a life filled with love and shared moments. Now, whenever someone says, "You'll be happy once you find your soulmate," she can't help but feel bitter. It's hard to understand why people would think that way. Why wouldn't they want to spend their entire life loving just one person? What's wrong with being content with what you have? But this particular comment really got under her skin. Maybe it was the way the nurse seemed so casual about it, like it was nothing more than a passing thought. Or maybe it was the fact that she

Triggering Event: She noticed him, her manager, laughing too loudly with the new girl at the register. The same laugh he used to share with her during their breaks. A sharp pain pierced her chest as she remembered their shared jokes now turned into foreign syllables. Her grip tightened around the mop handle, knuckles turning white. She'd been here for decades, and this was how they repaid her loyalty? A bitter taste rose in her throat. She decided then that they would pay.
Generated Assessment: She felt like an old man in a body that refused to cooperate. Every step felt labored, every breath a chore. They treated her like a relic from another era—a reminder of a time when things were simpler, when the world moved slower. Now, everything seemed to be rushing past her, leaving her behind. It wasn’t just her age; it was the way she looked, the way people saw her. Younger generations couldn't understand why someone like her still worked in the service industry. They didn't care about her stories or the memories she held within these walls. All they cared about was getting their orders quickly and moving on. It was as if she was invisible except when she made mistakes. Then, suddenly, she was front and center, the one everyone pointed fingers at. The pressure was suffocating, making her feel like she was drowning in a sea of expectations. Each day, she went through the motions, but inside, there was a storm brewing. The laughter of strangers became a trigger, reminding her of what she once had, and what she could never have again. One look at the young woman by his side—her former friend, her confidant, her partner in crime—was enough to bring tears to her eyes. He was happy, free, while she was trapped in a life she no longer wanted. His smile told a story of joy and freedom, a contrast to the weight of responsibility she carried.
